awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Airborne and Surface Disinfection Using Narrow Band Ultraviolet Light-Emitting Diodes
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of airborne and surface disinfection using narrow band ultraviolet light-emitting diodes (UV LEDs). UV emitters have a wide range of applications in airborne and surface disinfection, bio-medical and analytical instrumentation, fluorescence sensing, curing, and phototherapy. The traditional sources of UV lamps contain either mercury, xenon, argon, deuterium, or an excimer. All are considered unsatisfactory as they are bulky, fragile, expensive, low efficiency, have a limited life span, toxic, and only capable of emitting at a few specific wavelengths. Another alternative is the UV LED, which combines compactness with a nontoxic material composition, a lower power consumption, a quick response time, a long lifetime, and tunable emission across the entire UV region. Additionally, the nanowire form factor is ideal for integrating the light-emitter within the filter fabric for enhancing antibacterial and particulate filtration in air/surface purification and disinfection systems. Broad benefits to society including the new technologies, socioeconomic and environmental impacts as well as commercial potential are expected for such nanowire emitters.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of high-performance narrow band UV LEDs for airborne and surface disinfection. The disinfection UV LED technology aims at inactivating the spreading of microorganisms living in indoor spaces otherwise people are at risk of infection. The current common disinfectants include chemical sprays and hand and body washing. These approaches fail to kill viruses, bacteria, fungi, and microbes in real time. The chemical substances usually contain contaminants and raise health concerns. Disinfection UVC LEDs, however, are a rapid tool for inactivation, and environmentally friendly. The narrow band UVC LEDs are produced using the following steps: 1) synthesizing nanowire UVC LED structures using molecular beam epitaxy; 2) integrating optical bandpass filters into the LEDs to attain narrow band LEDs; and 3) combining nanowire UVC LEDs with current white-light LEDs to form a smart disinfection lighting-system. Like visible color LEDs that have revolutionized lighting and display, UVC LEDs are set to provide disinfection solutions in both air and on surfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_street_address: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

por.por_cntn:
Team 2464, UVwire Disinfection, consists of Victor (Ha Quoc Thang) Bui (Entrepreneur lead), Barsha Jain (Co- Entrepreneur lead), Jerry D'Alessio (Industrial mentor), and Hieu P T Nguyen (Technical lead) completed the National Science Foundation (NSF) I-Corps program during the 2022 Winter Cohort #2. As a result, we have performed over 115 customer discovery interviews. This program helped us to validate our value propositions and develop an efficient business model canvas. We have learnt several important suggestions from the customer discovery. For instance, we are suggested to focus on obtaining patents before the startup is launched, or Hospital, operation room constructors are those who take care of UV lighting disinfection installation.

With these customer discovery inputs, we found that current ultraviolet lighting technologies have not met the expectations for efficient surface/air/water disinfection applications. The successful implementation of our nanowire LEDs can eventually solve the current problems that current technologies are facing. Before starting this project, we have had several value propositions, however, those were not clearly defined and quantified. Joining this I-corps program, we received important feedback which definitely helped us improve our business model canvas. We could be able to identify our most potential customer segment as the Airborne and Surface Disinfection and validated it. Further, we could modify the value propositions, validate them, and develop our final business model canvas.

Moreover, we have received several technical comments regarding our product development. They have shown a clear interest in our technology/product and offered an academic-based project.

In summary, from our customer discovery, we could validate that nanowire LEDs are suitable for airborne and surface disinfection applications. The output power, efficiency and reliability of our nanowire LEDs need to be further improved before employing them in practical applications. Our immediate plans are to improve the device performance/product development and seek supports from NSF SBIR/STTR, and PFI grants.


Last Modified: 05/02/2023
Modified by: Hieu P Nguyen
